Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 08:41PM Kathy36 wrote: Hi Liz, I was having that exact same experience, a lot, when I first went on Aromasin. I bought an airline ticket, a new dress, and booked a hotel room for a friend's wedding in Charleston. One night, I was sitting at my desk, working and thinking how much I was looking forward to the wedding, when I  glanced at the date and realized she was getting married that night.  I lost a bike for good on the street, couldn't find doctor's offices I'd been going to for years, etc. Things got a lot better, though, after about six months. Hang in there.  Kathy

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2011 10:10PM Kathy36 wrote: I wanted to report back on the upshot:  The guy at Aetna gave me a long explanation about how first I have to meet my deductible, then I have to meet my out of pocket expenses, then we can get the show on the road with no more extortion, er, extra fees. Well, at least that sum wasn't a co-pay. But isn't a deductible pretty much the same thing as an out-of-pocket expense?  So didn't I pay the same fee twice?? Any day now, they're bound to come up with a third way of saying "Give us your money just because we said.":  "...yes, m'am, and then you need to meet your hand-it-over-and-no-one-will-get-hurt surcharge."

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 03:09PM - edited Apr 27, 2010 11:17PM by Kathy36 Robin's right: I WAS TALKING ABOUT YOU GUYS!! The outpouring of emails I got last January just floored me. I was having dinner with a friend who works at the Science Times and was telling her about them, and she suggested this piece. The story's kind of a tribute to the board. I don't post a lot, but I lurk and I feel so connected to people on here. The story's also a call to the medical community to find a way to do more innovative research, NOW.   My agent just forwarded on this email and I wanted people to see. it. Here's to every one of you.  <<I read Katherine Russell Rich's piece in the Times and was inspired. I admire Katherine's ability  to approach her medical care with courage and tenacity. But more so, I was affected by the description of the online survivor's group of which she is part. I have always found that no matter where you are--even if you don't speak the language or understand the customs--women will take care of their own. It's reassuring to hear that this is true of cyberspace as well.>> With love and hope, as much as we can muster, Kathy
Posts.Title: Kathy Rich and NYT Article RobinWendy RobinWendy

Posts.Content: May 6, 2010 07:05PM Kathy36 wrote: Browner6: The hormonal was called Cytadren. You had to take it with a steroid chaser. It's really an old jalopy of a hormonal by now--the only people who seem to use it anymore are body builders--but it might be worth a try. It did right by me for a long time.  Xeloda, on the other hand, made me sick as a dog, too. Though to be fair, I notice a lot of people on here have had an easy time with it.  Chocolate Lover: I agree. We're all inspirations and support to each other on here. Very grateful this place exists.   To everyone who wrote nice posts: Thank YOU GUYS so much.
Posts.Title: Kathy Rich and NYT Article RobinWendy RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 07:02PM Kathy36 wrote: Fine work!!!!!!!! Many congrats. Yesterday, when I was waiting for my dr.'s apt, a woman nearby got to talking with me and said: "In the time since you were diagnosed, a lot has changed.  Now, if breast cancer is caught early, it's almost 100 percent curable." She was clearly a patient, and I didn't think it was my place to correct her, but it did make me think how it's dangerous to have that kind of misinformation floating around. Great that you're getting the word out. Knowledge is power, even if the knowledge makes us uneasy.
Posts.Title: NYT Notes Andrea Mitchell's BC controversy EnglishMajor EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2011 10:53AM - edited Sep 17, 2011 10:55AM by Kathy36 I think because a lot of media stories have given them that impression.  Plus, a lot of the cancer centers were spinning the truth for a while. I once went to a lecture at Sloan Kettering where the head of breast cancer, Larry Norton, stood up before an auditorium of women with breast cancer and proclaimed, "We have cured breast cancer!" No lie. When, disbelieving, I complained to my oncologist, she said, "Oh I hate when he does that."

Posts.Content: Kathy36 wrote: I saw Fitztwins' post and know exactly how she feels. So if it helps anyone: I've lived with Stage 4 breast cancer for 18 and 1/2 years now. The cancer's active, but we keep beating it down. Right now, I'm on taxotere and a cane. (Nobody can agree on why I'm having walking problems: one guys says a problem with T5, one swears L5, another says some trouble with cauda equina; I'm going to beat them all with the cane if they don't get it together soon!) It's been a bumpy year, heathwise: pneumonia, parasites from India, the usual Stage 4 commotion. But there's also been a bunch of joy: I started a new book, a psychological thriller where I'll get to stab a socoiopath guy to death with a pen. (Fun! And oh so cathartic! And I think I'm going to name him after the b-hole oncologist who saw me in the hospital for pneumonia and without knowing much about my case, really knowing only that I was Stage 4, told me to get my affairs in order and make my peace with my relatives.) I won a Guggenheim fellowship, so that's keeping me afloat. But mostly, it's the smaller things I'm loving the most: the gorgeous weather right now, getting to see a friend in from Florida, figuring out the blessings that are tucked away in each day. But really, didn't mean to write about me. Just mainly wanted to say: I've lived for 18 and 1/2 years with Stage 4 breast cancer, and other people out there will too.  Much love, Kathy  Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Why do I feel we are being overlooked cmhartley blondiex46

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2010 08:29AM - edited Jan 28, 2010 10:05AM by Kathy36 Myra,  I've been on Xeloda for seven months now, and had a terrible time for a long time at first. BAD stomach stuff, headaches, dizziness, days in bed with utter exhaustion, couldn't keep weight on. YOU HAVE ALL MY SYMPATHY. But the Xeloda has been getting me good results and I'm glad now I hung in and worked out solutions. First, My onc dropped the dose down and that helped a lot. You might want to investigate that. Also, you might get relief if you take it one week on, one week off--I'd ask, if you're not already doing that, if you can. And the vomiting/diarrhea was causing me to get badly dehydrated without knowing it. Now, if I have any of that, I make sure to drink a truckload of liquids, especially Gatoraide or anything with electrolites. It was the dehydration that was mainly causing the headaches and exhaustion. So we cut down on the dose, I figured out how to manage some of the side effects (ate a lot of bananas and rice to combat the diarrhea), and my body had time to adjust to the Xeloda. Now I find each cycle gets easier and I can happily live on this stuff. Good luck. Kathy

Posts.Content: Kathy36 wrote: All this sprig, I was on Epogen for anemia and Fasolodex for cancer.  My cancer continued to progress.   Now a growing body of evidence shows that Epogen can speed up turmors, as well as cause strokes and heartattacks.  My question is, If I was on Eopegen, and Epogen can speed up turmors, and my tumors did speed up, how do I know whether the Fasolodex worked or not? Ie, is there any way they can say the Fasolodex wasn't working when it could have been the Epogen wreaking havoc? Log in to post a reply
